content.match_overview: Bournemouth (8th, 53 points) host Aston Villa (7th, 60 points) in a pivotal clash for European qualification. Bournemouth are unbeaten in five matches, including a controversial 2-1 win at Arsenal, while Villa have won six of their last seven league games[1][5]. Both teams need maximum points - Bournemouth to secure Conference League qualification and Villa to maintain their slim Champions League hopes[1][12]. Historically, Villa edge H2H with 6 wins to Bournemouth's 5, but the Cherries have scored late equalizers in two of the last three meetings[1][14].

citations.description: Match preview with H2H stats and league context
BTTS trends and recent form analysis
Opta win probabilities and positional analysis
Late goal patterns and lineup insights

team_news.raw: Bournemouth miss Lloyd Kelly (thigh) but welcome back Tyler Adams. Villa lose Youri Tielemans (muscular injury) with Boubacar Kamara likely replacing him[8][10].

home.projected_xi: Kepa; Huijsen, Zabarnyi, Kerkez, Smith; Cook, Tavernier; Semenyo, Adams, Kluivert; Evanilson

away.projected_xi: Martinez; Cash, Konsa, Torres, Digne; Kamara, McGinn; Bailey, Rogers, Ramsey; Watkins

asian_handicap_analysis.analysis: Villa's +0.0 line at 2.09 offers value given their recent xG dominance (2.38 vs Bournemouth's 1.81 in last meeting)[3] and superior big-game experience. Despite Bournemouth's home advantage, Villa have created 1.67 xG/away game vs Bournemouth's 1.45 xGA/home[15][17].
asian_handicap_analysis.raw: The 0.0 line essentially makes this a pick'em despite Villa's 7-point table advantage. Models suggest 41% Villa win probability vs 35.1% Bournemouth[4], creating 15.9% edge on the Asian line compared to 1X2 market.

key_player_matchups.title: Ollie Watkins vs Marcos Senesi
key_player_matchups.content: Watkins has 4 assists in 5 H2H appearances. Faces Bournemouth's weakest aerial CB (Senesi wins 48% duels)[7][14].
key_player_matchups.raw: Watkins' movement vs Bournemouth's high line (6.3 offsides/90, 3rd highest) could prove decisive[15][17].

key_player_matchups.title: Alex Scott vs Douglas Luiz
key_player_matchups.content: Bournemouth's press-breaker (83% pass accuracy) faces Villa's midfield enforcer (2.3 tackles/90)[7][10].
key_player_matchups.raw: Luiz has covered 12.3km/90 in last 3 away games - could neutralize Scott's creative influence[10][17].

betting_insights.insight: 75% chance (1.33 odds) - occurred in 7/9 Bournemouth home games & 6/7 Villa away[5][6]
betting_insights.raw: Bournemouth concede 1.2 GPG at home; Villa scored in 11 straight league games[1][6].
Villa's last 6 away games averaged 3.2 goals[6]; Bournemouth's last 5 home: 3.0[15].

betting_insights.insight: Villa 2-1 most probable (11% model chance vs 8.5% implied)[4][13]
betting_insights.raw: 6 of Villa's last 7 wins came by 1-goal margins; 4/5 Bournemouth losses <2 goals[6][15].

prediction.reasoning: Villa's superior xG (2.38 vs 1.81 last H2H[3]) and clinical finishers (Watkins 23% conversion vs Bournemouth's 18%[15][17]) should edge a high-tempo match. Bournemouth's late rally likely insufficient against Villa's game management.

content.my_say: This south coast clash pits Andoni Iraola's gegenpressing upstarts against Unai Emery's European veterans in what promises to be a tactical chess match with continental consequences. Watch for Villa's trademark '22nd minute surge' - they've scored 6 goals between 20-25 minutes in away games this term[17] - against Bournemouth's vulnerability to early crosses (47% conceded from wide areas[15]). With both managers' continental ambitions hanging in the balance, expect a match decided by marginal gains: a mistimed offside trap, a set-piece innovation, or perhaps another controversial VAR intervention to write the next chapter in this growing rivalry.
